node.title: No change to booster program after advice from ATAGI
node.alt: A woman wearing a face mask talking to a nurse.
node.description: The national expert vaccine group has recommended there be no widespread change to Australia's vaccine booster program, except for severely immunocompromised people, who can receive a booster shot two months after their second dose.
node.content: ["The national expert vaccine group has recommended there be no widespread\u00a0change to Australia's vaccine booster program in response to the emergence of the Omicron variant.", "However, the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) is recommending severely immunocompromised people get a booster shot two months after their second dose.", "Chief Medical Officer Paul Kelly said ATAGI had reviewed evidence from around the world about whether it should shorten the time interval.", "\"Just a quote directly from them, 'There is no evidence to suggest that an earlier booster dose of the current COVID-19 vaccines will augment the protection against the Omicron variant',\" he said.", "\"There is one difference there, in relation to the immunosuppressed population, where that is seen as a third dose, [the booster] can be given at a minimum of two months after the second dose.", "\"But, [with] the general population, the advice from ATAGI remains a six-month gap between the second dose and the booster program. So, in summary \u2014 no change.\"", "Professor Kelly also said both Moderna and Pfizer had announced they were looking at tweaking their booster shots to respond to the Omicron variant.", "He said more information on the variant was continuing to come to light, including details on how transmissible it is.", "\"It is definitely replacing Delta in South Africa as the main COVID-19 virus,\" he said.", "\"They have no real evidence at the moment of an increase in severity.", "\"They are seeing a rise in hospitalisations in one of the provinces \u2026 but\u00a0even the hospitalisations they are seeing with the Omicron variant are not any more severe than in previous waves.\"", "More to come."]
